Beyond Vietnam

By ERIC GARLAND
Daniel Ellsberg gave a speech
tentatively called "The Future of
Nuclear Destruction" Monday
night at Hopkins. His talk,
however, turned out to be more a
recounting of the elimination of
one's past, of a government
setting its destructive sights on an
individual rather than on a
country.
Old photographs of Ellsberg,
the shots on the back covers of
his books, show a man

and a Peter Falk smile, ready for
Challenge and change. In Shriver

thinned grey hair and a

45 years. He could have been one
of the prisoners of war stepping

years ago, only he was a prisoner
tracked by his own government,
gone for five •years without a
career and cut off from old
friends.
His speech came as part of the
Continental Walk for
Disarmament and Social Injustice
and the CCAPL-Chaplain's Office
series on nuclear arms. As a
crowd of about 350 settled into
their auditorium seats, drumbeats
rose slowly from the back of the
hall. Thirty or so marchers
entered Shriver, among them
Japanese Buddhist monks and
ragged long- distance walkers.
With placards reading "Jobs
not Bombs" and "Feed the Cities

solemnly down the aisles, using
rough sticks to beat leather
paddles at a deliberate pace. As
the procession made its way to

of the monks propped up a
ten-foot purple-and-gold standard
that sported a red sun and
Japanese inscriptions. Dick
Freeman, a member of CCAPL
and local organizer of the Walk,
introduced a couple of the
Walkers for short speeches, then
gave a background sketch of APL
activities.
The Applied Physics Lab, with

By BOB BUCHANAN
The financial health of this
institution is entrusted to a
handful of men: President
Muller, a strong University
chieftain who possesses more
than superficial knowledge of the
ways to effectively manage
business here; Robert Bowie, the
Vice-president for Business
Management, who has a direct
say on the decisions involving a
budget of 151 million dollars,
and Budget Director Norman
Krueger, who more often than
not ends up explaining the details
of the Hopkins ledger because of
the extraordinary time
commitments and public
evasiveness of the other men.
But there is another, though
seldom heard from outside of
administrative walls, who has
very much to do with the
relatively good financial times
enjoyed at Hopkins. In his office,
located next to Bowie's plush
quarters in the eastern end of the
second floor of Garland Hall,
University Treasurer George D.
Stewart directs the investments,
placing endowment and other
equities and funds to yield the
earnings so essential to the
continued economic fortune
here.
Stewart is, by all accounts, a
competent, able officer, working
for ten years as a successful
professionaLinvestment man out
Df New York City before arriving
on the Homewood scene. His
track record has remained an admirable one. While the unit
value of the University's
investment pool, a figure
unaffected by inflation, etc., has
been roughly constant since his.
arrival; earning from endowment
and equity and other funds have
increased a full 68 per cent.
Endowment income equaled
$7,265,371 in 1975, representing
a 5.64 return on investment. A
significant turn for the better by
the stock market, the usual
determinant of earnings, has not
materialized; the bulk of the
credit for the desirable state of
affairs regarding University
investment coffers must go to the
treasurer.
Endowment funds at the
University today total slightly in.
excess of 150 million dollars with
other separate investment
monies, including workingi

capital, adding another 50
million dollars to that total. 65
per cent of Hopkins assets are in
stocks and other equities, and the
remaining 35 per cent in fixed
income securities, with short
term notes accounting for a small
percentage of this category.
The job of managing the
investments of the University is a
complex and demanding one,
requiring complete, constant
knowledge of the stock market's
action. The investment
committee of the board of

trustees, headed by Robert H.
Levi, is responsible for the
development of the philosophy
and policy of the University in
the investments area; they work
closely with Stewart. While the
treasurer's immediate overseer is
Muller, who is himself an ex
officio member of the board
committee, he is finally
answerable to the committee as a
whole.
Three professional investment
firms assist Stewart in the routine
operation of the investment pool.

In Boston, the Putnam Advisory
Company calls the shots. Weiss,
Peck, and Greer assist in the
decision-making through their
offices based in New York, while
Miller, Anderson, and Sherrerd
aid Stewart from Philadelphia.
"These men deal with the
corporations which have stocks
listed by the Securities and
Exchange Commission. Each of
them is told they're responsible
for what security investments
should be made," Stewart said.

administration were seen as a

mode: their emphasis on budget
figures and cash flows was
thought to undercut the
concentration of deans and
presidents on the more scholarly
endeavors. Times have changed.

Specifically, he defends
Hopkins' lack of a minority
recruitment program by saying
that they do not recruit anyone
because they "do not want to
engage in reverse discrimination"
and have "no evidence that our
school is not known to black
applicants.
It is strange that
Dr. Muller seems to see only the
porribilities of discrimination or
reverse discrimination, omitting
the very obvious alternative of
equality. Furthermore, it is by no
means clear that the concept of
reverse discrimination has any
real meaning. It continues to be
the subject of much debate both
in academic journals and in the
press, has been decided
differently by various lower
courts, and has yet to be ruled on
by the Supreme Court.
In addition, Dr. Muller's
conception of recruitment is an
odd one. Even Johns Hopkins'
ownundergraduate recruitment
effort is designed to attract
capable students, not simply to
inform them that Johns Hopkins
exists. A positive recruitment
effort is particularly important in
the case of black students, as
there is substantial evidence
(much of which is summarized in
the 1975 report by William
Battle Associates to HEW on
"The Supply of Minorities,
Women, and Minority Women in.
Health Occupations.") that the
process by which blacks (and
women) select a career in
medicine is very different from
the same process in white males.
in order to be truly equitable, a
recruitment program
must
provide accurate information
sufficiently far in advance on
course requirements,
preparations for MCATs, etc., as
well as taking into accound and
counteracting the psychological,,
social, and economic barriers
which many blacks face in
choosing to aim for a career in
medicine.
Dr. Muller's remarks on the
destructive aspects of the intense
competition for medical school
are telling. He calls it
"horrible, "' and asks whether we
want a "physician cadre in this
country who have had to
compete almost like animals." He
adds that because of the
competition, undergraduates will
'do almost anything within
reason to get a good grade,
including cheat. '(it is not
surprising that Hopkins' honor

system failed when even the
resident considers cheating to
be within reason.) But Dr. Muller
sees no alternatives, indicating
either a lack of creative thinking
or a lack of true concern for the
problem.
__
It should be pointed out
that the undergraduage grades
which are the object of this
intense competition, the MCAT
scores which admissions
committees are so concerned to
keep up to a certain standard,
and personal interviews with
applicants have been repeatedly
demonstrated to have virtually
no correlation (and in some cases
even an inverse correlation!) with
success either in medical school
or as a physician. (See H.G.
Gouch, "The Recruitment and
Selection of Medical Students,"
in Psychosocial Aspects of
Medical Training, 1971, for a
summary of this research.)
The failure to implement an
active recruitment program
directed towards minority
students, coupled with the
continued reliance on admissions
criteria which have been shown
to be useless as predictors of
performance, and discriminatory
as well, shows Hopkins' lack of
concern with its role in
perpetuating the white
domination of the medical field.
Certainly Hopkins is not solely
responsible for the position of
blacks in medical and other
health careers, but as one party
which has contributed
substantially over the years to
the present situation, one would
hope that the institution would
recognize its responsibility to
contribute toward rectifying the
situation. Members of the
Hopkins University community
who were, quite rightly,
concerned with the university's
rather symbolic action of
awarding a degree to Princess
Ashraf should be at least as
concerned with the actions of
their university which have a very
real impact on the lives of black
Americans. Concerned students
and faculty, at Homewood and at
the medical institutions, should
put firm and continued pressure
school
on
the medical
administration to institute
recruitment and admissions
policies designed to attract
minority students.

the Department of Health Care
Organization at the Johns
Hopkins School of Hygiene and
Public Health.
